items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 1pm and 5pm, Friday 4th February. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.540mAODN at 2:45pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.53m above tide tables, Wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th February.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible over the next few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days due to sustained high water levels caused by the natural tide locking effect in the Broads. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Also, overtopping of the railway embankment at Haddiscoe New Cut has caused a reduction in the flood alert threshold. The Environment Agency and Network Rail are currently on site and working to resolve the issue. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Friday 4th February.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as overtopping waves and spray are expected to continue as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible on the high tide between 07:45 and 09:15 tomorrow morning, Friday 04/02/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Worsening coastal conditions are expected to continue on subsequent tides as wind strength is expected to increase. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message in 12 hours or as required with updated information.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as overtopping waves and spray are expected to continue as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible on the high tide between 07:15 and 10:00 tomorrow morning, Friday 04/02/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Worsening coastal conditions are expected to continue on subsequent tides as wind strength is expected to increase. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message in 12 hours or as required with updated information.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible over the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible over the next few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days, due to sustained high water levels caused by the natural tide locking effect in the Broads. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Also, overtopping of the railway embankment at Haddiscoe New Cut has caused a reduction in the flood alert threshold. The Environment Agency and Network Rail are currently on site and working to resolve the issue. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Friday 4th February.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 12 noon and 4pm, Friday 4th February. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in the surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.680mAODN at 2pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.60m above tide tables, Wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th February.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 12 noon and 4pm, Friday 4th February. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.680mAODN at 2pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.60m above tide tables, Wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th February.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 15:45 on 04/02/2022.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide expected to affect coastal and tidal locations this afternoon, Friday 4 February. Flooding is possible two hours either side of high tide, between 1pm and 5pm this afternoon, with strong winds and unsettled weather causing higher water levels than normal. Flooding will affect lower lying locations nearest the coast throughout this area, between Whitstable and Margate, particularly around Seasalter. The unsettled weather is likely to continue over the coming days so some further periods of flooding are possible this week, we will issue further messages if required. Please be careful in areas around the coast during this period of concern and avoid contact with flood waters present. We will continue to monitor this situation, and have staff prepared to respond if needed. This message will be updated or removed by 6pm this afternoon. For those who need it, the total water level for Sheerness is forecast to be 3.60m AOD at 14:45 on Friday, 04/02/2022.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 12 noon and 4pm, Friday 4th February.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.980mAODN at 2:30pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.72m above tide tables, Wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Friday 4th February.

This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon on 03/02/2022 between 11:00 AM and 01:00 PM. The areas most at risk are around Canal Foot, where over-topping is expected, and Storth Sandside. Impacts are also possible at low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days which may result in flood warnings being issued over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 02:06 PM on 05/02/2022. High tides today, 04/02/2022, are not expected to reach the Flood Alert level. Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 12:06 PM and 04:06 PM on 05/02/2022. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 04/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming high tides. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry between 02:00 PM and 02:30 PM, Eastford Road between 02:15 PM and 02:45 PM and Arpley Bridge between 02:30 PM and 03:00 PM on 04/02/2022. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. 
The high tide on Friday evening 04/02/2022 is not expected to reach flood alert. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 05/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00 AM and 01:00 PM on Thursday the 03/02/2022. Braystones Beach is likely to be most affected with some over-topping expected. Other areas at risk include Low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Millom including Ravenglass and Annaside.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning or as the situation changes.
